sub_topic: Find the covariant derivative of a tensor field on a manifold.
message_1: Consider the tensor field on a two-dimensional manifold given by $T = x^2\;\partial_x \otimes dx + y\;\partial_y \otimes dx + xy\;\partial_x \otimes dy$. Find the covariant derivative of $T$ with respect to the connection induced by the standard Euclidean metric on the manifold. Evaluate the derivative at the point $(1,1)$.
message_2:
To compute the covariant derivative of the tensor field $T$, we first need to find the Christoffel symbols of the second kind for the standard Euclidean metric on the two-dimensional manifold. The Euclidean metric is given by $g = dx^2 + dy^2$, and its inverse is $g^{ij} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. The Christoffel symbols are given by:

$$\Gamma^k_{ij} = \frac{1}{2} g^{kl} (\partial_i g_{jl} + \partial_j g_{il} - \partial_l g_{ij})$$

Since the Euclidean metric is constant, all its partial derivatives are zero, and therefore all the Christoffel symbols are also zero:

$$\Gamma^k_{ij} = 0$$

Now we can compute the covariant derivative of the tensor field $T$. The covariant derivative of a $(1,1)$ tensor field is given by:

$$(\nabla_i T)^k_j = \partial_i T^k_j + \Gamma^k_{il} T^l_j - \Gamma^l_{ij} T^k_l$$

Since all the Christoffel symbols are zero, this simplifies to:

$$(\nabla_i T)^k_j = \partial_i T^k_j$$

Now we can compute the partial derivatives of the components of $T$:

$$\partial_x (x^2) = 2x$$
$$\partial_y (x^2) = 0$$
$$\partial_x (y) = 0$$
$$\partial_y (y) = 1$$
$$\partial_x (xy) = y$$
$$\partial_y (xy) = x$$

Thus, the covariant derivative of $T$ is given by:

$$\nabla T = \begin{pmatrix} 2x & y \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \partial_x \otimes dx + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & x \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \partial_y \otimes dx + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & x \end{pmatrix} \partial_x \otimes dy + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \partial_y \otimes dy$$

Finally, we evaluate the covariant derivative at the point $(1,1)$:

$$\nabla T(1,1) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \partial_x \otimes dx + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \partial_y \otimes dx + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \partial_x \otimes dy + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \partial_y \otimes dy$$
